articles.headline: Chosen by Mississippi Democrats, Shy Trucker Is at a Crossroad
articles.snippet: Robert Gray won the Democratic primary even though he never campaigned, and his own mother did not know he was running until she saw the ballot.
articles.abstract: Robert Gray won the Democratic primary even though he never campaigned, and his own mother did not know he was running until she saw the ballot.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — Only three people who had ever met this man, Robert Gray, knew that he was running in the primary for governor of Mississippi.

articles.headline: Marketing to Sports Fans Online, With Help From Google and Social Networks
articles.snippet: As brands try to align themselves with football games beyond television, Google, Facebook, Twitter and Snapchat shop around new marketing products.
articles.abstract: As brands try to align themselves with football games beyond television, Google, Facebook, Twitter and Snapchat shop around new marketing products.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the National Football League season begins on Thursday, Google will not be merely sitting on the sidelines.

articles.headline: Patrick Drahi Positions Himself to Be a Player in U.S. Cable
articles.snippet: Mr. Drahi, a French-Israeli billionaire, has charted a course to prominence in the cable industry that prizes expansion and relies heavily on debt.
articles.abstract: Mr. Drahi, a French-Israeli billionaire, has charted a course to prominence in the cable industry that prizes expansion and relies heavily on debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — When the French-Israeli billionaire Patrick Drahi bought a St. Louis cable TV company in May and was mentioned as a potential suitor for Time Warner Cable, it may have been the first time many Americans had heard his name.

articles.headline: Companies Struggle to Comply With Rules on Conflict Minerals
articles.snippet: The Dodd-Frank Act requires companies to disclose their use of minerals mined in warring parts of Africa, a challenging task that involves tracking long and disjointed supply chains.
articles.abstract: The Dodd-Frank Act requires companies to disclose their use of minerals mined in warring parts of Africa, a challenging task that involves tracking long and disjointed supply chains.
articles.lead_paragraph: A pink My Little Pony balloon does not usually evoke images of rifle-toting warlords in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Still, Party City Holdings, the decorations and costumes retailer, recently disclosed a possible link to securities regulators, helping to put it near the bottom of a list ranking companies on their compliance with laws against using minerals mined in war-torn regions across Africa.

articles.headline: Apple and Other Tech Companies Tangle With U.S. Over Data Access
articles.snippet: Government conflicts with Apple and Microsoft reflect heightened resistance by businesses intent on demonstrating efforts to protect customer information.
articles.abstract: Government conflicts with Apple and Microsoft reflect heightened resistance by businesses intent on demonstrating efforts to protect customer information.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an investigation involving guns and drugs, the Justice Department obtained a court order this summer demanding that Apple turn over, in real time, text messages between suspects using iPhones.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, David E. Sanger and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: For Online Sports Videos, the Action Is No Longer on the Field
articles.snippet: Young sports fans are increasingly drawn to a digital parallel world where videos of skateboarding, snowboarding, surfing and other “action sports” dominate.
articles.abstract: Young sports fans are increasingly drawn to a digital parallel world where videos of skateboarding, snowboarding, surfing and other “action sports” dominate.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Anyone who went to the Apple iTunes store to buy a movie in mid-August might have noticed that sitting in the digital queue, next to blockbusters like “Mad Max: Fury Road,” was the seemingly obscure title “We Are Blood,” which was not exactly a movie, but a video consisting mostly of skateboarders performing tricks.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton to Show More Humor and Heart, Aides Say
articles.snippet: Staff members say the noise and distractions of modern campaigning have obscured these sides of Mrs. Clinton’s personality.
articles.abstract: Staff members say the noise and distractions of modern campaigning have obscured these sides of Mrs. Clinton’s personality.
articles.lead_paragraph: There will be no more flip jokes about her private email server. There will be no rope lines to wall off crowds, which added to an impression of aloofness. And there will be new efforts to bring spontaneity to a candidacy that sometimes seems wooden and overly cautious.

articles.headline: Decoding Steve Jobs, in Life and on Film
articles.snippet: The efforts to paint Steve Jobs as either hero or villain miss a larger truth: He can be both and still be worthy of acclaim.
articles.abstract: The efforts to paint Steve Jobs as either hero or villain miss a larger truth: He can be both and still be worthy of acclaim.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly four years after Steve Jobs died, a debate is still raging.

articles.headline: Migrants Who Survived Shipwreck Are Grateful, but Disillusioned
articles.snippet: The 2013 sinking of a flimsy boat carrying more than 500 people off the Italian island of Lampedusa was a signature moment in Europe’s migration crisis. Survivors share their stories.
articles.abstract: The 2013 sinking of a flimsy boat carrying more than 500 people off the Italian island of Lampedusa was a signature moment in Europe’s migration crisis. Survivors share their stories.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANDVIKEN, Sweden — As tens of thousands of migrants run the gantlet of dangers to reach Europe, Natanael Haile, a refugee from Eritrea now living in Sweden, is struggling to get over his nightmarish journey.

articles.headline: Restaurant of the Future? Service With an Impersonal Touch
articles.snippet: Eatsa, the first in a chain of quinoa restaurants with national ambitions, is almost fully automated.
articles.abstract: Eatsa, the first in a chain of quinoa restaurants with national ambitions, is almost fully automated.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s a new quinoa restaurant in San Francisco — yes, quinoa restaurants are a thing in San Francisco, so that’s not what’s noteworthy. At this restaurant, customers order, pay and receive their food and never interact with a person.

articles.headline: A New Wave of Migrants Flees Iraq, Yearning for Europe
articles.snippet: Emboldened by media coverage showing their countrymen and fellow Arabs fleeing the war in Syria, many who had resisted leaving during past crises now see a chance to go.
articles.abstract: Emboldened by media coverage showing their countrymen and fellow Arabs fleeing the war in Syria, many who had resisted leaving during past crises now see a chance to go.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Having sold his car for $4,600, and then some of his wife’s jewelry, and having loaded his smartphone with photographs of his five children, all that was left for Haider Abdella to do was say goodbye.

articles.headline: Chicago’s Fiscal Problems Dog Rahm Emanuel’s 2nd Term as Mayor
articles.snippet: Amid financial woes and increasing violence, Mr. Emanuel is also facing a hunger strike by a group of residents protesting plans for a closed school.
articles.abstract: Amid financial woes and increasing violence, Mr. Emanuel is also facing a hunger strike by a group of residents protesting plans for a closed school.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — It was supposed to be a run-of-the-mill town hall meeting, standard fare for a city contemplating a new budget year.
